Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal: Collaborative Research: Density-Dependent and Density-Independent Effects on the Non-Breeding Season Dynamics of a Migratory Bird
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues a 25-year study of long-distance migratory birds during the non-breeding season in Jamaica. Over the next five years, the researchers will measure how birds' physical condition and survival are influenced by population size and climate. Survival is expected to decrease as population size increases, a phenomenon known as regulation. However, survival also responds to factors such as weather that act independently of population size, a process known as limitation. Understanding how population regulation and limitation influence survival and abundance is necessary to predict how future environmental change will affect migratory birds. Since climatologists forecast increasing drought in the Caribbean, results from this research will provide critical insights into the consequences of climate change on the behavior, abundance, and ultimately the evolution of these species.

This project will facilitate the professional training of two graduate and over 20 undergraduate students in the US, as well as Jamaican students and scientists. The investigators will continue their existing collaborations with Jamaican wildlife agencies and local conservation groups, and will communicate their research results to scientists, policy makers, and citizens in the U.S. and the Caribbean. Data from the project are available electronically.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research we conducted in Jamaica supported by NSF LTREB funding builds on more than thirty years of field studies on migratory birds.  This work was designed to test hypotheses concerning how density-dependent processes and climate (precipitation) in winter affect birds? body condition, the timing of spring migration, annual survival, and carry-over effects into the migratory and subsequent breeding seasons. Our research focused on testing a crucial, but untested assumption underlying many migrant bird studies, namely, that climate, particularly rainfall, has a direct effect on food availability in the winter season and that this has critical consequences for both within and between season ecological and evolutionary phenomena in migratory birds. In addition, our research constituted one of the only efforts to understand the strength, scale, and functional form(s) of density-dependent processes that operate during the winter period to regulate populations of migratory animals primarily by impacting survival.

Through a series of intensive observational and experimental studies we have demonstrated that precipitation drives phytophagous insect availability directly and indirectly through its influence on plants. Insect availability then determines the body condition of migratory birds over the winter period and this determines winter departure schedules and breeding ground arrival dynamics ? both of which determine reproductive success on breeding grounds. Annual adult survival is strongly impacted by birds? body condition and food availability in winter.  Furthermore, as the density of adult birds increases in good habitat, their annual survival declines.  This was not the case in the low suitability habitat where individuals continued to be limited by resources more than by density.  Using both long-term observational and experimental (irrigations, food reductions, adult removals) studies we have demonstrated that both density-independent and density-dependent factors combine to drive events that carry-over to determine migration survival and reproductive success on breeding areas.  This unique and unprecedented long-term research program has determined how overwintering migratory birds respond to climate, thereby providing unprecedented insight into the future consequences of climate change on the behavior, abundance, and ultimately the evolution of these species. Overall, this 30 year research program has contributed significantly to our understanding of the ecology of the full annual cycle, highlighting the science in a framework that is now used research, education and conservation for many species across the globe.

Finally, this project facilitated the professional training of six postdocs, eight graduate students and over 50 undergraduate students and numerous colleagues from around the world. We also worked carefully with Jamaican wildlife agencies and local conservation groups and Jamaica, the Caribbean and North America more broadly to communicate our research results regarding the importance of understanding events throughout the full annual cycle to the conservation of migratory birds.
